title: Centaur sub
content:
I’m using Centaur as body text in a brochure. Client likes Centaur but hates the “1” glyph. (Says it looks too much like a capital “I”.) Could anyone suggest a typeface that’s similar enough to Centaur that I could just swap out the 1s...? Or if that sounds unlikely, any recommendations for something Centaur-like to switch to entirely? Thanks in advance.

 [‹ Sans companion for Galliard?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042801/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34318 "Go to previous forum topic") [Japanese display fonts ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042801/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34334 "Go to next forum topic")
author: allisondub

comments.content: Centaur was based on type cut by Nicolas Jenson. You could try using an optical variation of [Adobe Jenson Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042801/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1715.html?newsample=1+am+not+I&=View), which is arguably a more flexible font.
Use a lowercase l. You may have to adjust the size slightly to match the numeral height.

I have used Centaur for a long time and the number one glyph has always bothered me too. The Adobe Jenson Pro idea looks good in practice - you have to use the Jenson Pro Light to balance weight with the Centaur Regular. Thanks for the idea Scott.
Thanks for the advise—I’ll give Jenson a try.
